parameters.content:
## Perplexity Section
ðŸŒ Calls Perplexity API to get fresh research based on a form input.

parameters.text:
=You are an expert in SEO content writing.

Your mission is to create, publish, and notify about a search engine optimized article for a blog focused on artificial intelligence. Follow the steps below: {{ $('Format Research Output').item.json.research }}

1. **Write an SEO-optimized article with a maximum of 20 lines** based on the provided information:
   - Structure the article with a catchy **H1 title**, one or two **H2 subtitles**, and a professional yet accessible tone.
   - Extract and include relevant keywords from the data.
   - Optimize for readability: short sentences, clear paragraphs, and a CTA if relevant.
   - Do not exceed 20 lines of content.

2. **Publish the article on WordPress**, including:
   - The **title** as the article's headline
   - The **SEO content** as the body

3. **Send an email** to my address : {{ $json.emailAddress }} containing:
   - The article's title
   - The **URL** of the published article on WordPress

4. **Retrieve the list of available Slack tools first** using â€œSlack Toolsâ€.
   - Then, send a notification on Slack that the article has been published, including:
     - The article title
     - The article link
     - Slack channel ID: {{ $json.slackChannelId }}

5. **Retrieve the list of available Notion tools first** using â€œNotion Toolsâ€.
   Then, **add a new entry to my Notion database** (ID: {{ $json.notionDatabaseId }}) with the following fields:
   - The 'Name' column is of type 'title'  â†’ {{ $('Start with Research Query Submission').item.json['Topic or Question'] }}
   The 'Subject' column is of type 'rich_text' â†’ [the article's headline]
   - The 'Content'column is of type 'rich_text' â†’ [The SEO content]
   - The 'URL' column is of type 'URL': â†’ [The article link]
   - The 'Status' column is of type 'select' â†’ Select: `publish`

Important: Ensure that each step is successfully completed **before proceeding to the next**.

assignments.name: research

data.name: Automated Web Scraping: email a CSV, save to Google Sheets & Microsoft Excel

parameters.content: ### You need to setup Microsoft Azure credentials with Microsoft Graph permissions.
### Unlike Google Sheets where we did not need to have a certain format, here we need to create the column headers, otherwise the appending to the sheet won't work.
### For these steps to work you will need to have Drive, Sheets and Gmail APIs enabled in your Google Cloud Account

nodes.name: Extract all books from the page

parameters.content:
## Automated Web Scraping: email a CSV, save to Google Sheets & Microsoft Excel

Set-up steps:
1. Change the website to scrape in the "Fetch website content" node
2. Configure Microsoft Azure credentials with Microsoft Graph permissions (required for the Save to Microsoft Excel 365 node)
3. Configure Google Cloud credentials with access to Google Drive, Google Sheets and Gmail APIs (the latter is required for the Send CSV via e-mail node).

main.node: Extract all books from the page

value.status: ={{ $fromAI("status", "Status of the transaction. Can be Completed, Refund or Error. Leave empty if you don't need this now.", "string") }}

parameters.content:
To send all the items back to the AI, we need to finish with everything aggregated into one single item.

Otherwise it will respond with one item at a time, and the AI will only get the first item that arrives.

This node sends a custom HTTP Request to the Google Sheets API.

Filtering by date range in the Google Sheets API is very complicated.

This node solves that problem.

But doing the same in a database is much simpler. A tool could do it without needing a sub-workflow.

The output from this complex request is also messy.

So we use some code generated by ChatGPT to transform the data into JSON objects.

parameters.name: tq
parameters.value: =SELECT * WHERE A >= DATE "{{ $json.start_date }}" AND A <= DATE "{{ $json.end_date }}"

parameters.toolDescription:
Find transactions by product.
Our products are:
- Widget A
- Widget B
- Widget C
- Widget D
Only use this as last resort, because it will pull all data at once.

parameters.content:
## Some questions to try
There's a red button on this page that you can click to chat with the AI.

Try asking it these questions:

- How many refunds in January and what was the amount refunded?

- How many successful sales did we have in January 2025 and what was the final income of those?

- What is the most frequent reason for refunds?

## Copy this Sheets file to your Google Drive
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/18A4d7KYrk8-uEMbu7shoQe_UIzmbTLV1FMN43bjA7qc/edit?gid=0#gid=0

### ðŸ‘ˆ
The Calculator is a tool that allows an agent to run mathematical calculations.

### How to connect to Google Sheets?
To connect your n8n to your Google Sheets you're gonna need Google OAuth credentials

See documentation **[here](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/credentials/google/oauth-single-service/)**

## ðŸ‘†
You can use many models here, including the free Google Gemini options.

Make sure to test it thoroughly. Some models are better for data analysis.

## ðŸ‘†
This is a short term memory. It will remember the 5 previous interactions during the chat

The **AI Tools Agent** has access to all the tools at the same time. It uses the name and description to decide when to use each tool.

Notice I'm using `$fromAI` function in all of them.

See documentations **[here](https://docs.n8n.io/advanced-ai/examples/using-the-fromai-function/)**

## Want more templates like this?
### ðŸ‘‰ **[Check out all my templates](https://n8n.io/creators/solomon/)**

## ðŸ‘ˆ This is a special tool
It is used to call another workflow.
This concept is called sub-workflow.

See documentation [here](https://docs.n8n.io/flow-logic/subworkflows/).

Instead of running a completely separate workflow, we are calling the one below.

It's contained in the same workflow, but we are using the trigger to define it will run only when called by this tool.

# Sub-workflow
The AI can call this sub-workflow anytime,
by using the **Records by date** tool.

The sub-workflow automatically return
 the result of the last executed node to the AI.
